articles.headline: Beautifying the World With Amazon Ingredients
articles.snippet: In a retail market keen on the word “natural,” exports of Brazil’s beauty products have been rising quickly.
articles.abstract: In a retail market keen on the word “natural,” exports of Brazil’s beauty products have been rising quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  Brazilians’ longtime devotion to the body beautiful  whether it be spending fortunes on perfumes and cosmetics, slimming down to fit into minuscule swimsuits or revealing body waxing  is paying off.

articles.headline: In Primary, Tech’s Home Is a Magnet
articles.snippet: For presidential candidates campaigning in Silicon Valley, the place to be is  Google’s headquarters.
articles.abstract: For presidential candidates campaigning in Silicon Valley, the place to be is  Google’s headquarters.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For presidential candidates campaigning in Iowa, the place to be is the state fair. Diners are popular in New Hampshire. But for those visiting Silicon Valley, it’s the Googleplex.

articles.headline: Pakistan Court Lets Exile Back to Run Again
articles.snippet: The ruling on Nawaz Sharif, a former prime minister, is a direct challenge to the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.
articles.abstract: The ruling on Nawaz Sharif, a former prime minister, is a direct challenge to the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Carlotta Gall, Salman Masood and Helene Cooper.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall, Salman Masood and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Analysts Cut Expectations for Economic Growth
articles.snippet: Policy makers and Wall Street analysts are being forced to scale back their expectations for growth in the overall economy.
articles.abstract: Policy makers and Wall Street analysts are being forced to scale back their expectations for growth in the overall economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  The financial turmoil that began with the seemingly narrow meltdown in subprime mortgages is now forcing both policy makers and Wall Street analysts to scale back their expectations for growth in the overall economy.

articles.headline: States Begin Action on Subprime Lending
articles.snippet: The governor of North Carolina signed legislation that would protect subprime borrowers from highly risky adjustable-rate mortgages.
articles.abstract: The governor of North Carolina signed legislation that would protect subprime borrowers from highly risky adjustable-rate mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Michael F. Easley of North Carolina signed legislation last week that would limit the ability of mortgage brokers to charge customers above-market rates and prepayment penalties and would protect subprime borrowers from highly risky adjustable-rate mortgages.

articles.headline: More Iraqis Said to Flee Since Troop Increase
articles.snippet: Sectarian violence and new fighting brought by U.S.-led operations are accelerating the partition of the country into sectarian enclaves.
articles.abstract: Sectarian violence and new fighting brought by U.S.-led operations are accelerating the partition of the country into sectarian enclaves.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Aug. 23 — The number of Iraqis fleeing their homes has soared since the American troop increase began in February, according to data from two humanitarian groups, accelerating the partition of the country into sectarian enclaves.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Stephen Farrell

articles.headline: Foreclosures Force Britons to Ponder Shift to Fixed Rates
articles.snippet: While Americans fear an epidemic of foreclosures, brought on by the subprime mortgage meltdown, Britain is already suffering one.
articles.abstract: While Americans fear an epidemic of foreclosures, brought on by the subprime mortgage meltdown, Britain is already suffering one.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Aug. 22  Susan Whittaker was desperate. Four years ago, she purchased her first apartment in the town of Rochester, less than two hours east of London. But then interest rates started to rise, and the income from the small shop she ran with her partner no longer covered their adjustable-rate mortgage.
